definitions: shake involuntarily with slight rapid movements typically from cold fear or illness
examples: His hands began to tremor from the extreme cold weather
The leaves tremor gently in the light breeze outside

definitions: dig a long narrow hole or ditch in the ground for drainage defense or construction
examples: Workers will trench the field to install new water pipes
Soldiers had to trench defensive positions during the battle

definitions: flow slowly in a thin stream or in drops of liquid
come or go slowly in small numbers or amounts over time
examples: Water began to trickle down the rocks after rain
Blood continued to trickle from the small cut slowly
Voters started to trickle into the polling station early
Information about the incident began to trickle out gradually

definitions: treat someone or something without seriousness or respect in a casual dismissive way
examples: You shouldn't trifle with people's emotions like that carelessly
Don't trifle with dangerous chemicals in the laboratory please

definitions: produce a quavering or vibratory sound especially a rapid alternation of sung notes
examples: The opera singer could trill beautifully during her performance
Birds trill their morning songs outside my bedroom window

definitions: cut away unwanted or irregular parts to make something neat tidy or regular
make something thinner or reduce in size by cutting away excess material
decorate something by adding ornamental features especially around the edges
examples: Please trim the bushes before our guests arrive tomorrow
The barber will trim your beard to look more professional
The company needs to trim costs by reducing unnecessary expenses
Athletes trim body fat through diet and regular exercise
We plan to trim the Christmas tree with lights and ornaments
She decided to trim her dress with delicate lace borders

definitions: increase something to three times its original amount or make three times as much
examples: Sales are expected to triple during the holiday shopping season
The recipe says to triple all ingredients for larger crowds

definitions: achieve a great victory or success often against difficulties or strong opposition
examples: The team managed to triumph despite being the clear underdogs
She will triumph over cancer with determination and proper treatment

definitions: deliberately post inflammatory or provocative messages online to upset others or cause arguments
fish by trailing a baited line behind a slowly moving boat
examples: Some people troll comment sections just to start heated arguments
Don't feed the people who troll social media for attention
We plan to troll for salmon in the deep ocean waters
Fishermen often troll these waters during the summer months

definitions: move at a pace faster than walking but slower than running with short steps
examples: The horse began to trot around the training ring smoothly
Children trot alongside their parents at the busy mall

definitions: bring something into the exact shape position or adjustment needed for proper function
examples: The mechanic needs to true the bent wheel before reinstalling
Carpenters must true the door frame to ensure proper fitting

definitions: surpass or defeat someone or something by doing or producing something better
play a trump card to beat other cards in certain card games
examples: Quality will always trump quantity in fine dining experiences
Her experience should trump his enthusiasm for the job
He decided to trump my ace with his higher card
You can only trump when you're out of the led suit

definitions: proclaim or announce something loudly proudly or widely like the sound of a trumpet
examples: The company will trumpet its success in tomorrow's press conference
Politicians often trumpet their achievements during campaign season

definitions: shorten something by cutting off the top end or by removing the end portion
examples: The editor had to truncate the article to fit space requirements
Database systems often truncate long text fields automatically

definitions: make someone very tired or exhausted from physical activity or exertion
examples: The long hike will tucker out even experienced climbers completely
Playing with puppies all day can tucker you out quickly

definitions: pull something hard or suddenly with force typically with a sharp movement
examples: The child would tug on her mother's sleeve for attention
You need to tug the rope firmly to ring the bell

definitions: fall suddenly clumsily or headlong typically in an uncontrolled way
perform acrobatic movements such as somersaults typically in gymnastics or play
examples: The toddler would tumble down the grassy hill laughing joyfully
Books began to tumble from the overloaded shelf suddenly
Gymnasts tumble across the mat during their floor routines gracefully
Children love to tumble on soft playground surfaces safely

definitions: cover an area of ground with grass or lay turf on bare soil
examples: The landscapers will turf the entire backyard next weekend
We need to turf this area before the rainy season

definitions: engage in a vigorous struggle or scuffle typically involving physical grappling
examples: The two players began to tussle over possession of the ball
Dogs often tussle playfully in the park during playtime

definitions: teach a student individually or in small groups typically giving private lessons
examples: She will tutor struggling students in mathematics after school hours
Many college students tutor younger children to earn extra money

definitions: make or cause to make a sharp vibrating sound like a plucked string
examples: The guitar strings twang when plucked with too much force
You could hear the bow twang as the arrow was released

definitions: make small adjustments to something to improve or fine-tune it
twist or pinch something sharply typically causing momentary pain
examples: Engineers need to tweak the settings for optimal performance results
Let me tweak the recipe to suit your dietary preferences
My grandmother would tweak my cheek when I visited her
Don't tweak your brother's nose even if he's annoying you

definitions: post a short message on the social media platform Twitter
make the short high-pitched sound characteristic of small birds
examples: Celebrities often tweet about their upcoming projects to fans
I plan to tweet photos from my vacation in real time
Birds tweet cheerfully outside my window every morning at dawn
Baby birds tweet constantly when they're hungry for food

definitions: twist strands or threads together to form string cord or rope
wind or spiral around something in a coiling or wrapping motion
examples: Craftspeople twine natural fibers to create strong rope
You need to twine these threads tightly for durability
Ivy plants twine around trees as they grow upward naturally
She would twine her fingers through her hair while thinking

definitions: shine with a light that repeatedly becomes brighter and dimmer like stars
examples: Stars twinkle brightly in the clear mountain sky at night
Her eyes would twinkle with amusement at his silly jokes

definitions: give or cause to give a short sudden jerking or spasmodic movement
examples: His eye would twitch whenever he felt stressed or anxious
The rabbit's nose began to twitch at the unfamiliar scent

definitions: repeatedly assign an actor similar roles based on their appearance or previous performances
examples: Hollywood tends to typecast action heroes in similar tough-guy roles
She worried directors would typecast her after playing the villain

definitions: arrange text and graphics on a page in preparation for printing
examples: The publisher will typeset your manuscript before printing the book
Designers carefully typeset each page to ensure proper formatting

definitions: act as an official who watches a game to enforce rules and make decisions
examples: She will umpire the championship baseball game this Saturday afternoon
Retired players often umpire youth sports leagues in their communities

definitions: offer goods or services at a lower price than a competitor
weaken damage or undermine something or someone in a subtle way
examples: Online retailers often undercut traditional stores with lower prices
The new store will undercut competitors to gain market share
His constant criticism would undercut her confidence over time gradually
Don't let negative thoughts undercut your chances of success

definitions: estimate something to be smaller or less important than it actually is
examples: Never underestimate the power of proper preparation for success
Many people underestimate how long home renovations actually take

definitions: be the basis or foundation of something lying beneath the surface
examples: Cultural values underlie many of our daily social interactions
Serious health issues may underlie these persistent symptoms

definitions: draw a line under a word or phrase in written text
emphasize or draw attention to the importance of something
examples: Students often underline key terms when studying for exams
Please underline all the verbs in this English exercise
These results underline the need for immediate action on climate
Recent events underline how fragile peace can be globally

definitions: support strengthen or form the basis or foundation for something important
examples: Strong research must underpin any serious academic argument or claim
Family values underpin the stability of many successful communities

definitions: draw a line under text to highlight it using an underscore mark
give extra emphasis or draw special attention to something important
examples: You can underscore important text in your digital documents easily
Programmers often underscore variable names to improve code readability
These findings underscore the urgent need for policy changes immediately
Today's events underscore how quickly situations can change unexpectedly

definitions: study a role in order to be able to replace the usual performer when necessary
examples: Young actors often understudy major roles to gain theater experience
She will understudy the lead actress throughout the show's run

definitions: assume financial responsibility for a project or accept liability for potential losses
support or guarantee something especially by providing funds or taking responsibility
examples: Banks underwrite mortgages after assessing the borrower's creditworthiness carefully
Insurance companies underwrite policies based on calculated risk assessments
Wealthy patrons often underwrite arts programs in their local communities
The government will underwrite the costs of this infrastructure project

definitions: reverse or cancel a previous action or its effects to return to an earlier state
unfasten release or loosen something that has been tied or fastened
examples: You can undo your last action by pressing control plus Z
It's impossible to undo the damage caused by those harsh words
Please undo your seatbelt only after the plane stops completely
Can you help me undo this knot in my shoelace

definitions: dig up something buried from the ground or excavate from the earth
discover something hidden secret or lost especially through careful investigation
examples: Archaeologists unearth ancient artifacts at the excavation site carefully
Dogs often unearth bones they buried in the backyard
Journalists unearth corruption scandals through persistent investigative reporting
Researchers unearth fascinating details about historical events regularly

definitions: make or become united uniform or whole by bringing separate parts together
examples: The new leader hopes to unify the divided political party
Sports events can unify people from different backgrounds temporarily

definitions: form or cause workers to form a labor union for collective bargaining
examples: Workers voted to unionize after months of discussing workplace conditions
Companies sometimes resist when employees attempt to unionize

definitions: release or set free from confinement or restraint especially suddenly or powerfully
examples: The storm will unleash powerful winds across the coastal region
Don't unleash your anger on innocent people around you

definitions: remove goods or cargo from a vehicle ship or container
examples: Workers unload trucks at the warehouse loading dock every morning
Please help me unload groceries from the car trunk

definitions: open a lock by turning a key entering a code or using another method
make something previously inaccessible or restricted become available or achievable
examples: Use your key to unlock the front door when you arrive
You can unlock your phone with your fingerprint or passcode
Education can unlock opportunities for a better future in life
This discovery may unlock new treatments for the disease

definitions: remove a mask or disguise from someone's face to reveal identity
expose the true character or nature of someone or something hidden
examples: The detective will unmask the villain at the story's climax
Protesters demanded authorities unmask the undercover officers present
The investigation aims to unmask corruption within the organization
Time will eventually unmask people's true intentions and character

definitions: undo twisted knitted or woven threads causing them to separate
investigate and solve or explain something complicated or puzzling
begin to fail or collapse gradually losing coherence or organization
examples: The sweater began to unravel after snagging on a nail
Carefully unravel the tangled yarn before starting your project
Detectives work to unravel the mystery surrounding the missing jewels
Scientists unravel the complex interactions within ecosystem networks
Their relationship started to unravel after years of unresolved conflicts
The peace agreement may unravel without continued diplomatic efforts

definitions: remove someone from a position of power authority or dominance especially in competition
examples: Voters may unseat the incumbent mayor in the upcoming election
The young challenger hopes to unseat the reigning chess champion
